awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Renewable and Environmental Chemistry - IREC
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Alena Kubatova and colleagues are requesting funding for their REU Site at the University of North Dakota. This project, funded by the REU Sites Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, provides a 10-week summer research experience for 2nd and 3rd year undergraduate students from primarily undergraduate institutions using interdisciplinary research projects at the intersection of chemistry, chemical engineering, and atmospheric sciences. The interdisciplinary design of the IREC research experience is intended to achieve a two-fold learning goal for all students involved: it highlights the chemistry principles underlying their work and demonstrates the relevance and significance of chemistry principles to other fields. The specific research projects are based on current expertise of faculty at UND and target development of renewable chemicals from lignin and lignocellulose, measurement and modeling of atmospheric processes, and the determination of contaminants in tribal wells. Research projects are pursued from the combined perspectives of organic, analytical and physical chemists, chemical engineers, atmospheric scientists, and geologists.

A distinguishing feature of the IREC (Interdisciplinary Renewable and Environmental Chemistry) REU is that all students are jointly mentored by a team of interdisciplinary faculty mentors, providing students with unique exposure to scientific approaches from different disciplines. The IREC experience focuses on underrepresented minorities, targeting students from tribal community colleges, through initial research projects at the college, followed by a summer research experience for both Native American students and their faculty at UND. As a part of the project, students receive training in science communication, community outreach, and research ethics. Besides enhancing the presentation abilities of IREC participants, this training helps motivate both young students and IREC participants to pursue science and science-related careers.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Chemistry Site: Interdisciplinary Renewable and Environmental Chemistry (IREC)  provided 10-week summer research experiences at the University of North Dakota (UND) for 28 undergraduate students from primarily undergraduate institutions.   REU participants explored interdisciplinary research projects at the intersection of chemistry, chemical engineering, and atmospheric sciences. A distinguishing feature of the IREC REU was joint mentorship of students by a team of interdisciplinary faculty mentors, providing students with unique exposure to scientific approaches from disciplines including organic, analytical and physical chemistry, chemical engineering, atmospheric science, and geology. The specific research projects targeted development of renewable chemicals from lignin and lignocellulose, measurement and modeling of atmospheric processes, determination of contaminants in tribal wells, etc. The work of these projects resulted in 26 presentations at national, regional, and local conferences and 4 published peer-reviewed papers with several additional papers still being submitted or in preparation. From all participating REU students 18 (64%) have completed BS degrees (others are still working on it), with half of those (47%) continuing in graduate STEM programs and 45% employed in STEM jobs.

The IREC experience focused on underrepresented minorities (13 students 46%), specifically (but not exclusively) involving students and instructors from a tribal community college through initial research projects at the college. Essential components of the research experience were intertwined training in science communication and community outreach. Making science accessible to a general audience?especially chemistry?can be challenging in any circumstance. It is perhaps even more so when working with students as young as kindergarten.  With the "science communication training," our REU participants were able to do exactly that by helping create an outreach program with a number of activities, including visits to Turtle Mountain Community College (TMCC), a local daycare center, and involvement in a Young Scientist and Engineer Academy (providing exposure to 80 participant annually). Besides providing the experience for community participants, we have seen the positive impacts of the activities on our REU students as they acted as workshop facilitators. Working together to develop and present outreach activities strengthened their interpersonal skills as a cohort. They also have a better understanding of different audiences and the diversity of the state, as they were provided with the opportunity to observe what kids, including Native American students, like about science.  One of the TMCC instructors is now a graduate student at UND and is working with ND EPSCoR's Center for Sustainable Materials Science.  But, perhaps more importantly, the participating science instructors have started using the activities that our REU students taught them in their own K-12 classrooms, and we hope that the impacts of our outreach will be felt for years to come.
